en_first_half: He remembered how once he had been walking down a crowded street when a tremendous shout of hundreds of voices—women’s voices—had burst from a side street a little way ahead. It was a great formidable cry of anger and despair, a deep, loud “Oh-o-o-o-oh!” that went humming on like the reverberation of a bell. His heart had leapt. It’s started! he had thought. A riot! The proles are breaking loose at last! When he had reached the spot it was to see a mob of two or three hundred women crowding round the stalls of a street market, with faces as tragic as though they had been the doomed passengers on a sinking ship. But at this moment the general despair broke down into a multitude of individual quarrels. It appeared that one of the stalls had been selling tin saucepans. They were wretched, flimsy
en_second_half: things, but cooking pots of any kind were always difficult to get. Now the supply had unexpectedly given out. The successful women, bumped and jostled by the rest, were trying to make off with their saucepans while dozens of others clamored round the stall, accusing the stallkeeper of favoritism and of having more saucepans somewhere in reserve. There was a fresh outburst of yells. Two bloated women, one of them with her hair coming down, had got hold of the same saucepan and were trying to tear it out of one another’s hands. For a moment they were both tugging, and then the handle came off. Winston watched them disgustedly. And yet, just for a moment, what almost frightening power had sounded in that cry from only a few hundred throats! Why was it that they could never shout like that about anything that mattered?

The shopman, however, was denying that the saucepans were of exceptionally poor quality. In his opinion they were the best quality. All his customers were of the same opinion, hence the quarrels. The women were clamouring for saucepans, willing to do without food or clothes or furniture, but not willing to do without saucepans. Winston watched them disgustedly, thinking that the revolution was a long way off yet. The idea that people could be so petty and selfish, even in the face of such overwhelming oppression, was a hard pill to swallow. He remembered the countless times he had seen people fighting over scraps of food, or arguing over who got to use the community bathroom first. It was as if they had lost all sense of what was truly important. The Party had done its job well, turning people against each other, making them so focused on their own individual struggles that they forgot about the bigger picture. Winston sighed and continued on his way, lost in thought. He couldn't help but wonder if the revolution would ever come, or if the people would continue to be held down by their own petty squabbles. As he walked, he noticed the telescreens watching him, their eyes ever vigilant, always waiting for someone to slip up so they could pounce. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he realized that he was being watched, that every move he made was being monitored and recorded. The thought sent a surge of adrenaline through his veins, and he quickened his pace, anxious to get back to the safety of his flat. But even as he walked, he knew that he wasn't safe, that the Party could get to him whenever they wanted. The thought was a constant presence in his mind, a nagging feeling that he couldn't shake. He wondered how many others felt the same way, how many others were living in fear of the Party's all-seeing eye. The thought sent a pang of sadness through him, and he couldn't help but feel a sense of hopelessness. Was this really the world they lived in now? A world where people were so afraid of their own government that they couldn't even walk down the street without being watched? It was a bleak thought, and one that Winston couldn't shake as he made his way back to his flat.

They were like the ant, which can see small objects but not large ones. Winston's thoughts were interrupted by the sound of the old man shuffling back into the room, his face flushed and his eyes glassy. He made his way back to the bar, his movements slow and uncertain, and Winston watched him with a mixture of fascination and disgust. The old man was a relic of a bygone era, a reminder of a time when life had been different, when people had been different. Winston wondered what his story was, what he had done before the Revolution, what he had lost. But the old man's face was a mask, a mask of age and weariness, and Winston knew that he would never know the truth.  As he sat there, lost in thought, Winston became aware of a figure standing in the doorway, watching him. It was a woman, a tall, dark-haired woman with a white face and a scar above her left eyebrow. She was dressed in a long, black coat, and she looked out of place in the dingy, rundown bar. Winston felt a jolt of recognition, but he couldn't quite place her. He looked away, hoping that she would go away, but when he looked back, she was still there, still watching him. He felt a shiver run down his spine as their eyes met, and he knew that his life was about to change in ways he couldn't even imagine.
